ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: explore many topics of human science

Knowledge about humanity, social science, political science...
Reading long articles and summarize the main points

I developed a strong argument skill and research writing skills. I developed a strong understanding of humans and science and was faced with conflicting yet interesting topics. I also developed a longer and stronger attention span and different way to approach a topic or question.
I developed speaking skills. Being an international student and not having English as my native language was quite challenging. But the group discussions in class helped a lot.

I have developed knowledge in understanding the various aspects that contribute to the building blocks of 'being human'. I've come to realize the importance of science and social knowledge that form the concepts society has created on certain identities to recognize distinctly or categorically human characteristics associated to.

Learning more about the history of human or its biology is very interesting, especially as a university student that does not have any some-sort of basic for the said course. I receive many great new information, and different views and approach to the matters of human science.

Being Human since 1945 provides deep historical thinking for the phenomenon in the real world. From this course, I developed a curiosity and realization that science has layers in its history that we should closely pay attention to. I also learned a lot about the complexity of science that utilizes numerous aspects of life to 'manipulate' society.
Everything in human sciences is up for debate.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
great reading materials and instructions
help me develop critical thinking
My teacher and classmates are very supportive. We covered a lot of topics and materials in the class, so we got a chance to learn things in different fields. Everything is perfect!
The course seemed to be a bit a longer than what I am used to however there were many breaks where stretch our legs, however the course was engaging and extremely interesting.
The professor gave lectures that even if the content was exciting he gave them with a monotone voice and not engaging the audience. He needed more dynamism and eye contact.

The course itself encompasses alot of topics from science to social which could sometimes be confusing, it would be nice to have a clearer introduction on how these topics correlate to one another and why we discuss them as they are.

I see no big weakness on the course, as it is very informative and helpful for those student that enjoy human science, but for a course in the summer session, I think it needs less material to deliver and focused on so it is not overwhelming for students.

Strength: insightful class discussion, thorough feedback on assignments, and accommodating teaching staff
Weakness: I find it hard to understand the undertone of the class theme each week, but I think it is because I am a social science student. It is a me-problem.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes.

Yes, I would. The course was engaging, I learned a lot and the professor was passionate about the subject at hand. They would often answer questions that we had offer guidance on our reflections research papers. The course involves engaging in arguments that relate to human science, medicine and human psychology.
Yes, I would. Nevertheless, I consider that the contents of the course are so vast that you cannot deepen in any of them. Sometimes it's better not to bite off more than you can chew.
Yes, I would recommend this course to other students interested in history and science.

If the students have the basic knowledge of scientific materials, then it can be very helpful and fun. But for a summer session class, I would say, choose the other class with less workload, so it will balanced with this course.

Yes! Being Human since 1945 provides a fun ride back in the history of science despite a complication that we also had to face in numerous reading. However, I believe that Doctor Simon and Adi did a great job in assisting the class to comprehend many complicated topics.
Yes, to any persons who might be interested in the history of sciences and preferably students of STEM major origin.
Absolutely! The course offered a philosophical structure on how to think about human sciences and our very existence.

narratives.question_text: How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments: Since I'm a high school student, it is my first time studying at a university. This experience allows me to have a better understanding of university courses. Also reading a lot of materials and lectures practice my English. I believe that I can accommodate the university courses quicker after I studied in Yale Summer Session. Besides, this class provides me with more knowledge about humanity and social science, which I'm interested in.

I will use the skills the I learned for writing my research paper in the future and in high school. I want to major in pharmaceutical research and the deployment of medicine. This course helps understand the human sciences and history behind the development of medicine and humans.

The knowledge and skills I learnt are crucial for me to understand how businesses operate. In this case, how to become a responsible consultant that considers not only the knowledge shared but the impact the knowledge shared can create, the looping effects in creating labels which reinforce an idea when projected onto someone or something, the development of identity and how an individual may react towards responses threatening the identity in the context of businesses, and so much more.
Receiving it as a basic knowledge for human science, will be an important experience for me to keep, I can also share it to others for discussions.
I will use it as a way of thinking, mainly because I will do my final thesis soon. It will help me to dig deep into the historical aspect of one phenomenon in today's world.

1. I'll try to become a good listener like Simon.
2. Science is always progressing and self-correcting. Do not appeal to science as if it's the ultimate authority.

extras.title: HIST S440 01/HSHM S400 01 - Being Human since 1945
